718284f.title: Manhattan: Central Park.
718284f.text:
TEN THOUSAND NEW YORK SCHOOLBOYS DRILLING IN CENTRAL PARK.
This is a great army of schoolboys from all boroughs of the big city, attired in white shirtwaists & dark knickerbockers, gave an exhibition drill in the physical exercises in the city's largest park last month before a distinguished company of invited guests, relatives & friends.  The purpose of this impressive demonstration, which was held under the auspices of the Public Schools Athletic League, was to show the results of physical and hygienic training in the schools.  Colonel Roosevelt, who was one of the spectators, spoke of the work of the League as a great force for good not only in the city but in the nation.

Dated:  June 10, 1913.  American Press Ass'n
Neg # 2333

718190f-b.title: Manhattan: Central Park - [View of the Arsenal Building.]
718190f-b.text:
Central Park: A set of 4 views of the Arsenal under reconstruction, photographed in a northeastward direction from in the Park, showing the Mrear of same with the menagerie to the south (frame structures on the right). Across the background are buildings on the east side of Fifth Ave. at about 64th Street. The corner stone of this structure was laid on July 4, 1847. Later it became the headquarters of the Park Police;
who still occupy same today (1938).
January 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
718190f-b.folder: Central Park & [View of the Arsenal Building.], Manhattan, NY

718191f-b.title: Manhattan: Central Park - [View of the Arsenal Building.]
718191f-b.text:
Central Park: A set of 5 views of the Arsenal under reconstruction as viewed westward (north and southward) from Fifth Ave. (foreground) at East 64th Street. This structure was erected in 1848 at a cost of 30,000 (as given in 1853). The City of New York purchased same in 1856 from the State for a sum of ~275,000. The first floor was used for Administrative offices while the 2nd and 3rd were occupied by the Museum, which later became the American Museum of Natural History. The Meteorological Observatory for years ocoupied a large upper room.
January 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
718191f-b.folder: Central Park & [View of the Arsenal Building.], Manhattan, NY

February 2, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

718215f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle.
718215f-a.text:
Central Park: The southwestern entrance at Columbus Circle and showing the Maine Monument there. On the right appears buildings on the south side of Central Park South (West 59th Street); the southern
confine of this central garden area.
About 1928.
Ewing Ualloway.
718215f-a.folder: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle., Manhattan, NY

718335f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Playgrounds [Ball ground and athletic fields and the Green.]
718335f-a.text:
Central Park: Ball Ground and athletic field, and the Green, in the southwestern corner of the Park, with Columbus Circle and Eight Avenue in the foreground. In the upper left hand corner Central Park West runs off the picture about 69th Street; and in the upper right hand corner may be seen the southern end of the Mall. The old sheepfold, between the West Drive and the 60th Street gate will be rebuilt in 1934 as an outdoor restaurant, The Tavern on
the Green.
In this aerial view the driveways, bridle path, and pedestrian pathways stand out very clearly.
About 1929.
Ewing Gallomay.
718335f-a.folder: Central Park & Playgrounds [Ball ground and athletic fields and the Green.], Manhattan, NY

718331f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Playgrounds [field on the North Meadow.]
718331f-a.text:
PLAYGROUNDSi
Central Park: Athletic Field in North Meadow, Pool and Harlem Heights in the foreground; the view is southeast from Central Park West, showing Fifth Avenue buildings from 95th Street south to the Plaza. The upper reservoir is seen in
the center background.
Wurts Brothers  May 21, 1930
718331f-a.folder: Central Park & Playgrounds [field on the North Meadow.], Manhattan, NY

718180f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park.
718180f-a.text:
Central Park: Aerial View from Hotel Sherry-Netherland at the south-eastern corner of the Park, showing the old Arsenal and the Zoo which is to be rebuilt in 1934, in the right foreground. To left may be seen the Green, or south meadow, and behind it Central Park West at 72nd Street. The Mall is in the center of the picture
just south of the Lake.
On the east side, at Fifth Avenue and 80th Street, are the buildings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and to the left of them the Lower Reservoir, rectangular in shape, which at the time of t picture is shortly to go into disuse, with the view of later it into a garden. The North Reservoir is the large body of water
above it.
Central Park West, from 72nd to 96th Streets, is shown at the 1eft.
Summer, 1930.
Ewing Galloway.

Central Park: Playgrounds, in the North Meadow, and tennis courts between the North Meeadow and the Upper Reservoir. The view is northeast towards upper Fifth Avenue. The driveway in the foreground is the West Drive. A gate house on the northern side of the Upper Reservoir may be seen at the extreme right.
May 10, 1931.
Varts Brothers.

718183f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - [Aerial view from Radio City.]

Central Park: Aerial view from Radio City (Gith Avenue and 5lst Street), showing the Park. Also showing the west side of town and the Hudson River. The Riverside Church, at 122nd Street, and the George lashington Bridge,
at 181st Street, stand out very clearly.
Aug. e, 1933
P. L. Sperr, photographer.

May 21, 1933.

718187f-a.folder: Central Park & [View of the Arsenal Building (rear).], Manhattan, NY

718179f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Aerial view from Radio City.
718179f-a.text:
(1)
Central Park: Aerial View from Radio City (Sixth Avenue and 51st Street), showing the Park and the Fifth Avenue side. In the center foreground may be seen the Pond, north of it tho l(all, then the Lake, of which the eastern bay is at thc northern end of the Mall and the main body on the west side of the Park, about 70th to 80th Streets. The bare spot further north is the site of the old reservoir; above it may be seen the nor reservoir, still in use. The buildings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art may be seen on the Fifth Avenue side at 81st
Street.
August 9, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, another view. In the southwestern quarter of the Park may bo seen a ball ground, and north of it the Meadow or Green. The 72nd Street cross drive separates the Green and
the Lake.
August 9, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718179f-a.folder: Central Park & Aerial view from Radio City., Manhattan, NY

718311f-a.text:
Central Fark: Pathway, near Harlem Heights, between the Loch and
Harlem Mere; the view is north.
May 18, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

718313f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Pathways.
718313f-a.text:
Central Park: Pathway, near Harlem Heights, where a battle of the
Revolutionary war was fought.
May 18, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

718318f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Pathways.
718318f-a.text:
Central Park: Pathway and rustic bridge near Indian Cave, at the
northern shore of the Lake.
May 17, 1933.
L. Sperr.

718307f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Pathways.
718307f-a.text:
Central Park, Pathways: A refreshment stand in the Park.
May 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

718330f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Playgrounds [baseball field in the southern end of the Park.]
718330f-a.text:
Central Park, playgrounds: the baseball field in the southern end of Central Park. This field was a part of the original plans for Central Park, and is shown on the 1858 map as a cricket field.
May 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718330f-a.folder: Central Park & Playgrounds [baseball field in the southern end of the Park.], Manhattan, NY

718329f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Playgrounds [field on the North Meadow.]

Central Park, Blaygrounds: athletic field on the north meadow, in
the north central portion of the Park.
May 18, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

portion of the Park, near the zoo.
M-y 21, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
4- Cg  Nien. 2e BO02
718328f-a.folder: Central Park & Playgrounds [in the south central portion of the Park.], Manhattan, NY

718327f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Playgrounds [southeastern portion of the Park.]
718327f-a.text:
Central Park, playgPounds: a smell children's playground near the
southeastern portion of the Park.
The four hotels in the background are, from left to right: the Pierre, the Sherry-Netherland, the Savoy-Plaza, and the Plazza.
May 21, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718327f-a.folder: Central Park & Playgrounds [southeastern portion of the Park.], Manhattan, NY

718398f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Sailboat pond.
718398f-a.text:
Central Park : The Sailboat Pool, near Fifth Avenue and 75th Street,
the westen edge of the pool; the view is north.
Two models of racing yachts, a big one and a small one, have crossed the pool from different directions and are coming together at the
finish. Their owners are waiting fon them.
May 17, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718398f-a.folder: Central Park & Sailboat pond., Manhattan, NY

718409f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Transverse roads [Transverse Road No.1].
718409f-a.text:
Central Park : Transverse Road No. 1, near the entrance at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street. The western end of the road is at 66th
Street.
The twin towers on the horizon, in the right background, belong to the El Dorado apartment building on Central Park West, 90th to
91st Streets.
May 21, 1933.
P. L  . Sperr.
718409f-a.folder: Central Park & Transverse roads [Transverse Road No.1]., Manhattan, NY

718204f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - West Drive.
718204f-a.text:

background.
May 17, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718204f-a.folder: Central Park & West Drive., Manhattan, NY

718216f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle.
718216f-a.text:
Central Park: The Columbus Circle entrance.showing to the left of same a small booth operated by the Free Milk Fund for the purpose of
feeding the unemployed.
May 17, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718216f-a.folder: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle., Manhattan, NY

718221f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle.
718221f-a.text:
Central Park : The Southwestern Entrance, originally known as the Merchants' Gate, at Columbus Circle, showing the monument erected to the sailors lost in the sinking of the EA)09 (the incident that
precipitated the Spanish-American War).
May 21, 1933.
L. Sperr.
718221f-a.folder: Central Park entrance at Columbus Circle., Manhattan, NY

718181f.title: Manhattan: Central Park - [General view] from Rockefeller Center, Radio City.
718181f.text:
Central Park, as seen from Rockefeller Center, (Radio City). Also shown is a general view of midtown Manhattan between the Hudson (left) and East (right) Rivers. Silhouetted against the Park is the West 59th skyline, consisting of the Essex House, Barbizon Plaza, N. Y. Athletic
Club and the Plasa Hotel buildings.
About 1934.
Rockefeller Center
Hamilton Wright
718181f.folder: Central Park & [General view] from Rockefeller Center, Radio City., Manhattan, NY

718199f-b.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Casino.
718199f-b.text:
Central Park: Workmen demolishing te Casino in accordance with Mayor LaGuardia and Park Commissioner Moses plan to return all public parks to the general public. During Mayor Walkers incumbency this structure was leased to a private restaurant corporation which through
its extreme prices created an exclusive atmosphere.
May 12, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

718199f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Casino.
718199f-a.text:
Central Park: Workmen demolishing te Casino in accordance with Mayor LaGuardia and Park Commissioner Moses plan to return all public parks to the general public. During Mayor Walkers incumbency this structure was leased to a private restaurant corporation which through
its extreme prices created an exclusive atmosphere.

718277f.title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Menagerie.
718277f.text:
Central Park, as seen from the Hotel Pierre (Fifth Ave., at East 61st Street), and showing a view northwesterly. Prominently shown in the foreground, (Southeastern corner of the Park) is the newly remodeled 2oo. The labor and funds being supplied by the United States Government and the W.P.A. The former presidential aspirant, Alfred E. Smith, is the honorary headkeeper.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
718277f.folder: Central Park & The Menagerie., Manhattan, NY

718404f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Seal Pool.
718404f-a.text:
Central Park: The Seal Pool, located in the center of the newly rebuilt Central Park 2oo. Note the animal houses in the background.
About 1936.
00ift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.
718404f-a.folder: Central Park & The Seal Pool., Manhattan, NY

718421f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Seal Pool.

Central Park's new zoo provides modern housing for its
wide variety of animals.
Sept. 1935

718410f.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Transverse roads [Transverse road No. 1].
718410f.text:

68th Street, at Central Park West.

718394f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - [Wading pool.]

Central Park.
"The Hotter It Is the Better They Like It"' Let that old thermometer roar. These youngsters didn't care. They had one glorious time of it in wading pool at Central Park
yesterday.
"P E A Photo"
From Review of Reviews Corp.

718206f-b.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Drives
718206f-b.text:
(1) Central Park: The West Drive, Central Park West, from 71st to 73rd Streets, in the background. The apartment buildings shown are the old Majestic and the Dakota, on either side of 72nd Street.

Notice the tree full of pigeons. Autumn, 1923.

P.L. Sperr.

(2) The West Drive, part of the exit branch for southbound traffic leaving the park at 72nd Street. In the background is Central Park West from 73rd to 72nd Streets, inclusive. May 17, 1933.

P.L. Sperr.

(3) The West Drive, near the Lake, showing Central Park West from 76th to 71st Streets. The buildings shown, from right to left, are the Church of the Divine Paternity (Universalist), the Kenilworth apartment house, the new San Remo, the Langham, the Dakota (the oldest in the picture), and the new Majestic. May 17, 1933.

P.L. Sperr.
Negative #1775
